intro: Bupleurum davisii, commonly known as the Davis' bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers are usually blue or purple, and it blooms in the spring. Bupleurum davisii is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and limited distribution.
